Title: Injection Head
Technical_Problem: Traditional needleless injectors require complex drug loading: install drug tube, draw medicine from vial using needle, separate tube from vial. Process is cumbersome and time-consuming.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Drug tube with chamber and micro-hole; B: Piston rod with piston; C: Rear end insertion into vial; D: Internal drug channel; E: Joint installation relationship
How_To_Achieve: Internal drug channel in piston rod enables in-situ aspiration from stored vial; one-way valve prevents backflow contamination
Design_Around: 1) External vial connection; 2) Pre-filled cartridge without on-device aspiration

Title: Needleless Injector Body and Needleless Injector
Technical_Problem: Previous needleless injectors require cumbersome operations where drug vial must be removed and drug tube separated from vial during extraction and injection. Process is inefficient.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Base with forward opening; B: Outer shell mounting on base; C: Internal pusher system; D: Supplementary drug pusher; E: Transmission device
How_To_Achieve: Transmission device converts rotational/linear motion to forward motion of supplementary drug pusher, compressing vial stopper during extraction
Design_Around: 1) Removable vial architecture; 2) Passive pressure equalization system

Title: Injection Head Assembly
Technical_Problem: Injection head components must be individually engaged with injector body; engagement process is complex requiring manual user operation and risk of incomplete assembly.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Injection head assembly for injector body; B: Injection head body with cavity and piston rod; C: Sequential insertion/rotation positions; D: Automatic locking/disengaging mechanism
How_To_Achieve: Sequential rotational engagement with automated unlocking triggered by continued rotation; eliminates manual component manipulation
Design_Around: 1) Manual component engagement; 2) Linear axial installation without rotation

Title: Injector Head Assembly, Injector Body and Injector
Technical_Problem: After injector head assembly installed and end cap removed, injector head body can rotate and be removed independently, leading to part loss and hygiene issues.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Injector head body with proximal cavity; B: End cap at distal end; C: Insertion and rotation capability; D: Elastic member compression; E: Blocking mechanism on rebound
How_To_Achieve: Elastic member rebounds when end cap removed to block rotation; forces end cap reinstallation before removal enabling unit removal
Design_Around: 1) Eliminate elastic member blocking; 2) Different disassembly control method

Title: Syringe Body and Syringe
Technical_Problem: Existing syringes with separable injection heads have inadequate end cap engagement. End cap can be easily disengaged creating safety risk during high-pressure injection.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Syringe body for injection head assembly; B: Separable injection head body and end cap; C: Outer shell and internal pusher; D: Distal opening for locking; E-F: Position-dependent constraint
How_To_Achieve: Outer shell diameter contacts end cap when unlocked preventing separation; radial gap forms at locked position allowing cap removal
Design_Around: 1) Eliminate sequential dependency; 2) Permanent end cap replacement

Title: Injection Head Assembly
Technical_Problem: Existing injection heads allow end cap removal before proper locking onto injector body. Creates severe safety hazard: injection head may be ejected during high-pressure injection.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Injection head main body with cavity and micropores; B: Piston rod component; C: End cap; D: Position-dependent constraint mechanism (blocks/allows based on position)
How_To_Achieve: Injector body acts as active constraint element preventing end cap deformation until locked position; state-dependent mechanical constraint
Design_Around: 1) Eliminate removable cap entirely; 2) Constraint source not from injector body

Title: Needleless Injector
Technical_Problem: Prior art needleless injectors require tedious multi-step operations: install drug tube, extract medicine using needle, separate from vial, then inject. Problematic in emergencies.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Drug storage component with pre-filled chamber; B: Injection component with piston assembly and micropore; C: Safety device between chambers; D: Sequential actuation component
How_To_Achieve: Sequential two-stage actuation: operating device first transfers drug to injection chamber, then triggers piston movement at predetermined position
Design_Around: 1) Eliminate pre-filled configuration; 2) Simultaneous rather than sequential actuation

Title: Needleless Injector
Technical_Problem: During pre-injection pressurization, piston pushrod tends to shift or displace prematurely, preventing proper pressurization and making injection impossible.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Injection component with chamber and micropore; B: Piston assembly movable between first/second positions; C: Position-dependent locking device with auto-unlock at second position
How_To_Achieve: Automatic position-dependent locking during charging stroke; precise release when maximum displacement reached allowing rapid injection
Design_Around: 1) Eliminate automatic unlocking; 2) Eliminate distinct position-based locking

Title: Injection Head Assembly
Technical_Problem: Existing injection caps are difficult to install correctly due to small size and complex structure. Users frequently fail to align cap properly with injection head.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Injection head with base, main body, cavity, micropores, first guiding component; B: Injection cap with opening and second guiding component; C: Cooperative guiding relationship
How_To_Achieve: Dual guiding rib system provides bi-directional rotational guidance regardless of initial installation angle; enables blind installation
Design_Around: 1) Eliminate need for predetermined orientation; 2) External visual/tactile alignment only

Title: Needleless Injector
Technical_Problem: Conventional needleless injectors require users to pull piston away when loading medicine, then push toward injection head when injecting. Two-direction operation is cumbersome.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Injection assembly with chamber and microholes; B: Piston assembly with passage; C: Actuation assembly with operating device; D: Transmission device for motion direction conversion
How_To_Achieve: Transmission device converts unidirectional forward user input into backward piston retraction; single direction for both preparation and injection
Design_Around: 1) Conventional sequential bidirectional operation; 2) Non-mechanical actuation for piston

Title: Disposable Needleless Injector
Technical_Problem: Conventional needleless injectors require users to draw medicine from external vials. Manual loading is time-consuming, risks air bubbles, contamination, and dosing errors.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Injection assembly with injection chamber; B: Movable medicine storage with pre-filled chamber, plunger, delivery pusher; C: Actuation with elastic element; D: Initial/activation positions
How_To_Achieve: Movable storage component transitions from disconnected to connected position; elastic element automatically drives medicine transfer after connection
Design_Around: 1) Eliminate movable storage component; 2) Use non-elastic actuation for medicine delivery

Title: Piston Rod for Needle-Free Injector
Technical_Problem: Medicine difficult to draw into drug tube cavity; during injection, medicine easily backflows from drug tube back to internal storage container. No precise flow direction control.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Rod portion extending axially; B: Piston portion distally connected to rod; C: Uni-directional seal structure with open state (aspiration) and sealed state (injection)
How_To_Achieve: Pressure-responsive seal automatically opens during aspiration allowing medicine entry; seals during injection preventing backflow via conical surface contact
Design_Around: 1) Eliminate internal storage container; 2) Constant full-flow pathway with no seal

Title: Holding Device for Storage Container
Technical_Problem: Traditional holding mechanisms either permanently fix containers or lack secure locking. Difficult to balance retention security during use with need for container exchange.
Claim_1_Elements: A: Holding device with housing; B: Operable component movably disposed on housing; C: Linkage mechanism; D: Two-state transition (prevent vs allow container installation/removal)
How_To_Achieve: Mechanical linkage between operable user interface and locking element creates controllable switching between locked and unlocked states
Design_Around: 1) Eliminate operator-controlled locking; 2) Automatic locking without operable component
